botanical_details.genus: Pyrus are deciduous trees or shrubs with oval leaves and scented white flowers in spring, followed by green or brown fruits, edible in some species

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in any well-drained, fairly moisture-retentive soil . The ideal pH is 6.5. Incorporate plenty of organic matter on thin soils. Choose a sheltered position in full sun. Suitable for all training forms, including espalier, cordon and fan-trained. Needs another cultivar for pollination. Keep a weed-free area of 60cm radius around the trunk. Thin fruit if necessary
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by grafting or budding onto a rootstock for fruit. Quince rootstocks are usually used
how_to_grow.pruning: Regular pruning required; a spur bearer. Prune according to form: cordons, espaliers and pruning established fans. Can also be grown as standards or spindlebushes. For further guidance see: pruning new pear trees, summer pear pruning, winter pear pruning, renovating pear trees
how_to_grow.pests: May be attacked by aphids, caterpillars, codling moth, pear blister mite, pear midge and pear and cherry slugworm
how_to_grow.diseases: Blossom wilt, brown rot, European pear rust, fireblight, pear scab and replant diseases may be troublesome
